title: Putin rejects deep concessions as Ukraine peace plan stalls
description:
Talks over a US-mediated Ukraine peace plan are moving, but slowly, with both Moscow and Kyiv continuing military attacks even as they negotiate.
Russia’s leadership believes its small battlefield gains in 2025 prove eventual victory is inevitable, which makes any serious compromise harder to accept.
fullText:
A “peace plan” while the war continues

More than three years after Russia’s full-scale invasion, diplomats are trying to turn a 28-point US-mediated plan into a smaller and more realistic proposal, now reduced to around 19 core points.
The talks focus on a step-by-step ceasefire, security guarantees for Ukraine, and some form of arrangement for occupied areas, but neither side wants to look weak at home.

Washington is presenting the plan as a way to stop the killing without forcing Kyiv into a formal surrender, while Moscow insists that any final text must recognise, directly or indirectly, Russian control over territories it currently occupies.

Small gains on the map, big impact on politics

On the battlefield, Russia has made only limited advances in 2025, capturing villages and small strips of land in eastern Ukraine at the cost of hundreds of thousands of cumulative casualties since the start of the war.
Even so, analysts say this slow “drip of victories” convinces Vladimir Putin that time is on his side, reducing his incentive to accept deep concessions.

Meanwhile, Ukraine remains under missile and drone attacks, with cities such as Kyiv facing periodic strikes on infrastructure and residential areas.
Stretched air defences and limited ammunition stocks make each new wave of attacks harder to intercept.

Pressure on Zelensky and his allies

For President Volodymyr Zelensky, it is politically impossible to accept any deal that looks like “trading land for peace”.
He repeatedly stresses that Ukraine will not surrender the Donbas region or give up its long-term ambition to move closer to NATO and the European Union.

At the same time, European countries are experiencing war fatigue, inflation and internal debates over using frozen Russian assets to fund Ukrainian defence and reconstruction.
In the United States, the Trump administration is trying to balance promises to “end the war quickly” with growing public frustration over the financial and human cost of continued support.

Why this matters for the rest of the world

European security: reshaping defence spending, NATO’s posture and military planning.

Global economy: disrupting energy supplies, fertiliser trade and grain exports.

International order: the outcome will be seen as a test of the world’s ability to respond to invasions and violations of sovereignty.

If the peace plan collapses, experts fear a long war of attrition, with largely static front lines but ever-rising human and economic costs.

title: Gaza’s shattered economy faces ‘worst collapse on record’, UN warns
description:
A new UN report says the Palestinian economy has suffered its worst collapse ever recorded, after two years of war in Gaza and severe Israeli restrictions.
GDP per capita has fallen back to 2003 levels, wiping out 22 years of development and leaving Gaza dependent on massive long-term aid to survive.
fullText:
Two years of war and decades of restrictions

According to the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the combination of Israel’s war in Gaza, repeated airstrikes and long-standing blockades has caused unprecedented economic destruction in the Palestinian territories.
By the end of 2024, average income per person had dropped back to levels seen more than 20 years ago, effectively erasing two decades of progress in health, education and infrastructure.

Gaza’s industrial base, commercial districts and agricultural land have been bombed or abandoned; water, power and sewage networks have been badly damaged.
Even in the West Bank, where there is no full-scale war like in Gaza, checkpoints, movement restrictions and falling investment have pushed the economy into its worst crisis since records began.

Among the 10 worst economic collapses since 1960

UN economists rank the Palestinian downturn among the ten worst national economic collapses since 1960, comparing it to severe civil wars and major natural disasters.
Millions of Palestinians are now dependent on humanitarian aid for basic food, while local businesses struggle to import materials, export goods or access credit.

Without coordinated reconstruction and a minimum level of predictability and security, the economy remains locked in pure “survival mode”.

A ceasefire that hasn’t brought real relief

A ceasefire came into force in October 2025, but limited airstrikes have continued, aid deliveries remain slow, and there is growing talk of a de facto partition of Gaza under security arrangements linked to the US peace plan.
For many families, this means living in tents or half-destroyed buildings, with unreliable access to water, food and electricity.

Humanitarian organisations warn that, without a deep change in access and mobility policies, meaningful reconstruction could take decades — if it happens at all.

Long-term risks for the region

Instability: extreme poverty and mass unemployment increase the risk of radicalisation and future violence.

Migration: more Palestinians may attempt to leave the region, putting pressure on neighbouring countries.

International credibility: the crisis tests the ability of the global community to respond to long-running emergencies in occupied and contested territories.

UN economists say Gaza will only be able to “produce more than it did before the war” with strong international support, reforms in governance and a gradual removal of the most restrictive measures.

title: New push to end Sudan’s devastating war meets resistance
description:
The US and regional partners are pushing a new ceasefire plan to end Sudan’s 30-month civil war, but neither of the two main armed factions has formally accepted it.
One side has even called the proposal “the worst yet”, raising fears that fighting and humanitarian catastrophe will drag on.
fullText:
A war that refuses to end

Since 2023, Sudan has been trapped in a brutal conflict between the national army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), a powerful paramilitary group.
The fighting has devastated cities, displaced millions of people and created one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises, with hunger rising across multiple regions.

Recently, a US envoy presented a “comprehensive plan” for a ceasefire during meetings in Abu Dhabi, backed by countries such as the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.
The idea is to silence the guns for several months, ease the flow of humanitarian aid and open the door to broader political negotiations.

Ceasefire rejected as ‘biased’

In public statements, Sudan’s top army general rejected the draft, calling it “the worst proposal so far” and accusing mediators of favouring the rival side.
Shortly before that, the RSF had announced a unilateral three-month ceasefire, seen by analysts as an attempt to score diplomatic points and ease pressure from foreign governments.

In practice, however, clashes continue in key areas, and reports of abuses against civilians keep emerging — especially in regions already scarred by ethnic tensions and mass displacement.

Humanitarian emergency on multiple fronts

The war has shattered Sudan’s fragile economy, disrupted harvests, destroyed infrastructure and forced millions to flee to remote areas or neighbouring countries.
Makeshift camps now shelter people with little or no access to clean water, sanitation, healthcare or schooling, leaving the country highly vulnerable to disease outbreaks and widespread famine.

Humanitarian organisations say that without an effective ceasefire and safe corridors, it is impossible to deliver enough aid to the hardest-hit zones.
While political and military leaders argue about power and security, ordinary families are simply trying to survive from one day to the next.

Regional and global stakes

Stability in Northeast Africa: the war is pushing refugees into Chad, Egypt and other neighbours, creating economic and political strain.

Global interests: regional and international powers are competing for influence in a strategically located, resource-rich country on a key corridor between the Red Sea and inner Africa.

Diplomatic credibility: repeated failures of ceasefire initiatives undermine trust in international peace efforts.

So far, neither side has shown real readiness to sacrifice battlefield gains for peace, leaving Sudan’s population trapped in a conflict with no clear end in sight.

title: Dormant Ethiopian volcano erupts after 12,000 years
description:
Ethiopia’s Hayli Gubbi volcano erupted for the first time in about 12,000 years, sending huge plumes of ash high into the sky and over the Red Sea.
Flights have been disrupted in parts of Africa, the Middle East and South Asia, but so far no deaths have been reported.
fullText:
A surprise from the Earth’s past

Located in Ethiopia’s north-eastern Afar region, the Hayli Gubbi volcano was considered dormant since prehistoric times, with no written records of previous eruptions.
Over the weekend it suddenly roared to life, launching ash columns up to 14 km into the atmosphere, clearly visible in satellite images.

Residents say the initial blast “sounded like a bomb”, with tremors and loud rumbling shaking nearby communities.
Experts note that, although unexpected, the eruption fits the natural cycle of volcanoes that can remain quiet for many thousands of years before re-awakening.

Ash clouds and flight disruptions

The ash clouds drifted across the Red Sea toward Yemen, Oman and parts of South Asia, forcing airlines to reroute or cancel flights for safety reasons.
Volcanic ash can damage aircraft engines and instruments, so aviation authorities prefer longer routes and delays rather than taking risks.

At the same time, meteorologists are tracking whether fine particles might affect air quality in distant regions, depending on wind patterns and weather systems.

Local impact and emergency response

So far, there are no confirmed deaths directly linked to the eruption, but nearby communities are dealing with ash fall, contaminated water sources and loss of grazing land for livestock.
The Ethiopian government and international agencies are assessing:

The need for additional evacuations from remote villages;

The impact on herders and pastoralists, the main source of income in the Afar region;

The risk of further explosive activity or lava flows.

Geologists have installed extra monitoring equipment to track tremors and changes in the volcano’s behaviour.

A reminder of global volcanic risks

Events like this show that, beyond wars and political crises, natural hazards can also disrupt the global system — from climate patterns to air travel.
Larger eruptions in more densely populated or highly connected areas could seriously affect supply chains, agriculture and even global temperatures.

For now, the priority is to protect local communities and keep aircraft safely away from the ash cloud, while scientists study a volcano that has “woken up” after millennia of silence.

title: The global AI race: US, China and Europe fight for the future
description:
Artificial intelligence is now a central battleground of power, with the US, China and Europe competing to lead in advanced models, AI agents and regulation.
New reports and summits warn that whoever sets today’s AI rules will shape economies, security and democracy for decades to come.
fullText:
From hype to hard power

In 2025, AI is no longer just hype: it already moves financial markets, automates factories, writes code and influences elections.
The AI for Good Global Summit and high-profile events in Europe and the US show governments, companies and international organisations racing to set standards before the technology runs ahead of control.

Experts argue that the rush to build ever more powerful models must be matched by clear rules on safety, transparency and accountability.

Different strategies: US, China and Europe

An analysis from Euronews highlights how the global contest for AI leadership mixes geopolitics, regulation and security.

United States: still leads in big tech companies and cutting-edge research, but faces intense debate over regulation and the concentration of power in a handful of firms.

China: is investing heavily in AI for commercial, military and surveillance use, while working to reduce dependence on foreign chips and software.

European Union: wants to be a leader in rules, with AI laws focused on fundamental rights, transparency and safety, even at the risk of falling behind in scale.

Executives from European startups warn that the bloc’s biggest challenge is retaining talent, as many engineers move to American or Asian companies in search of higher pay and access to top-tier infrastructure.

Democracy, disinformation and control

Reports on “digital democracy” show that governments are increasingly using technology to gain advantage, often at the expense of cooperation and civil liberties.
AI tools can:

Amplify disinformation campaigns;

Automate censorship and mass surveillance;

Help political actors micro-target voters with extreme precision.

At the same time, there is hope that AI can strengthen democracy by analysing complex policies, translating official documents and broadening citizen participation in public debates.

Why this race matters for everyday life

Decisions taken now about AI will influence:

Jobs: which professions are automated, transformed or newly created;

Security: from cyber-defence to autonomous weapons;

Privacy: how much personal data governments and companies can collect and use;

The global economy: countries that dominate AI may set technical standards and capture a large share of future value.

Regulators are trying to catch up with a technology that evolves faster than most legal systems, and the outcome will help define how fair — or unequal — the next wave of innovation will be.

title: US affordability crisis hits millions despite lower inflation
description:
Inflation in the US has fallen from its 2022 peak, but a severe affordability crisis remains, with families struggling to pay for housing, food and healthcare.
The issue is becoming a major political problem for President Trump, who promised to make life cheaper but now faces rising public frustration.
fullText:
Prices stopped exploding, but never went back down

Reports from major newspapers and financial analysts show that, although annual inflation has dropped to around 3%, prices built up over the past five years have stayed painfully high for millions of households.
Rents, groceries and health insurance premiums remain expensive, and wage growth has not fully kept up.

Many Americans in both big cities and smaller towns are counting every cent at the end of the month, even while working multiple jobs.

Bethlehem, Pennsylvania as a snapshot of the crisis

A detailed report from Bethlehem and the Lehigh Valley region in Pennsylvania shows families who, despite having steady jobs, rely on food banks and temporary shelters.

Young parents are sharing apartments with other families to split soaring rents.

Older residents are delaying medical appointments because they cannot afford the co-payments.

Small businesses see customers cutting spending back to essentials only.

This picture is repeated in communities across the country, feeding a sense of insecurity and political fatigue.

Political backlash and controversial proposals

The Trump administration promised to “fix inflation” and restore the American dream, but is now being criticised from both left and right.

Ideas under discussion include:

Introducing 50-year mortgages to reduce monthly payments, at the cost of very long-term debt;

Tightening work requirements for benefits like food stamps (SNAP) and Medicaid, which worries anti-poverty groups;

Adjusting or delaying tax credits that currently help low-income families pay for health insurance.

Polls show falling approval ratings for Trump on economic issues, with many voters saying that “no one in Washington” really understands the day-to-day pressure on their budgets.

A deeper structural problem

Economists say the problem is not just inflation, but also:

A shortage of affordable housing in dynamic job markets;

Wages that failed to keep pace with living costs over many years;

Student and medical debt weighing heavily on family finances;

A fragmented and expensive healthcare system.

Without structural change, even low inflation can coexist with high cost of living for a long time — and that will influence consumer behaviour, mental health and political stability.

title: Amnesty warns of a global human rights ‘backslide’
description:
Amnesty International’s latest State of the World’s Human Rights report says authoritarian practices and crackdowns on dissent are spreading worldwide.
The organisation points to conflicts, mass surveillance and attacks on migrants, women and LGBTQ+ people, warning of a “Trump effect” accelerating destructive trends.
fullText:
Authoritarian habits becoming mainstream

Amnesty’s 2025 report covers developments in around 150 countries and paints a worrying picture: governments using security laws, “fake news” narratives and moral arguments to silence critics and restrict freedoms.
Instead of being an exception, “state of emergency” measures have become routine in many regions, justifying arbitrary arrests, censorship and excessive force against protesters.

Conflicts and the cost to civilians

The report highlights how wars in Ukraine, Gaza, Sudan and other hotspots have brought enormous human costs, including attacks on civilians, mass displacement and the use of hunger as a weapon of war.
At the same time, the international response is described as selective: strong sanctions and condemnation in some cases, silence or weak reaction in others, depending on political alliances and economic interests.

Death penalty and shrinking civic space

Amnesty notes that global executions reached their highest level in a decade in 2024, driven by sharp increases in countries such as Iran, Iraq and Saudi Arabia, even as more states move slowly towards abolition.
In many places, human rights groups, journalists and activists face laws that restrict foreign funding, label NGOs as “undesirable”, and criminalise the sharing of critical reports — as seen in Russia, which has banned Amnesty’s activities.

The ‘Trump effect’ and the future

The report describes a global “Trump effect”, where anti-rights policies and rhetoric from Washington are used by other governments as justification for rolling back international commitments — especially on migration, gender equality, racial justice and climate.

To reverse the trend, Amnesty calls for:

Stronger international courts and accountability mechanisms;

Consistent, non-selective pressure against abuses, regardless of who commits them;

Real support, including funding, for front-line human rights defenders.

The organisation warns that, without sustained resistance, today’s emergency measures risk becoming tomorrow’s permanent normal.

title: EU–China relations enter a colder, more complex phase
description:
After the 2024 European elections, EU–China relations are shifting, with a stronger presence of far-right parties and renewed focus on “de-risking” from Beijing.
Europe now officially treats China as partner, competitor and systemic rival, creating a more fragmented and unpredictable policy landscape.
fullText:
A new political map in Brussels

The 2024 European Parliament elections weakened centrist parties and boosted the influence of right-wing groups such as ID and ECR.
Analysts say this results in more conflicting views on China within EU institutions — from those who advocate deep trade ties to those who demand near-total economic separation.

Partner, competitor and rival – all at once

Official EU documents describe China simultaneously as:

A partner on issues like climate change and global health;

An economic competitor in trade and technology;

A systemic rival in terms of political values and models of governance.

This “three-in-one” framing creates tension between member states more dependent on the Chinese market and those that prioritise security, human rights and strategic autonomy.

De-risking, not decoupling

Recent reports show that many European governments are trying to de-risk — reduce vulnerabilities in supply chains, critical technologies and infrastructure — without fully “decoupling” from China.

Steps include:

Reviewing Chinese investments in ports, telecom networks and energy assets;

Limiting exports of sensitive technologies;

Encouraging companies to diversify production to other Asian countries.

At the same time, major European companies lobby hard to maintain access to China’s huge consumer market.

Why this matters globally

EU–China relations affect:

Global trade: tariffs, subsidies and technical standards;

Green transition: cooperation or rivalry over clean energy, batteries and critical minerals;

Technology: competition in areas like 5G, AI and semiconductors.

How Europe balances its interests will influence the broader US–China rivalry and help shape the future of the global economic order.

title: Climate action in 2025: one summit, many unanswered questions
description:
Instead of multiple COPs, 2025 has one big UN climate event and several regional meetings aiming to accelerate the transition away from fossil fuels.
Experts warn that, even with fresh pledges, the world is still off-track to keep global warming close to 1.5°C.
fullText:
Fewer conferences, higher expectations

After three major climate meetings in 2024, 2025 brings a leaner calendar but higher expectations around one large global event and a high-level summit at the UN.
Leaders are set to discuss:

Emissions-reduction goals up to 2030;

Funding for climate adaptation in vulnerable countries;

“Loss and damage” funds for nations already hit by severe disasters.

Finance and trust gaps

Developing countries insist they cannot phase out coal, oil and gas without predictable financial and technological support.
Promises of climate finance from richer nations often arrive late or smaller than advertised, eroding trust in the entire negotiating process.

Without affordable credit for renewable energy, resilient infrastructure and social protection, many governments remain locked into cheaper, more polluting options in the short term.

Fossil fuels: accelerate, phase down or phase out?

The major political battle is over language: should the world accelerate the transition, phase down or fully phase out fossil fuels?
Oil and gas exporters argue for a long-term role for their resources, often emphasising carbon capture technologies; meanwhile, small island states insist on a clear phase-out to prevent their territories from literally disappearing under rising seas.

Without strong consensus, the risk is leaving 2025 with texts full of good intentions but weak enforcement mechanisms.

Real-world impacts in 2025

While diplomats negotiate, 2025 is already seeing:

Intense heatwaves and wildfires on multiple continents;

Urban flooding in cities with poor drainage systems;

Agricultural losses linked to droughts and extreme weather events.

Climate scientists warn that every year of delay in concrete action raises future costs in both lives and money, making adaptation far more difficult and expensive later.

title: A month of turmoil: conflicts and crises reshape the world
description:
From Gaza and Ukraine to Sudan and natural disasters in Asia and the Americas, November 2025 has been marked by overlapping crises.
Analysts say this level of simultaneous turmoil is straining humanitarian systems and speeding up a shift toward a more fragmented global order.
fullText:
Many crises, one global system under pressure

A recent overview of world events describes November 2025 as a month in which armed conflicts, natural disasters and political shocks combined into a global “stress test”.
While wars continue in the Middle East, Ukraine and Sudan, floods and landslides have hit parts of Asia, and powerful storms have battered regions of the Americas.

Each crisis has local causes, but together they put pressure on the same international system of aid, diplomacy and finance.

Political shocks and social unrest

On top of the conflicts, several countries are facing:

Cost-of-living crises and persistent inflation;

Protests against climate policies or austerity measures;

Tensions around elections and fragile transitions of power.

Reports from think tanks and forums such as the World Economic Forum describe a “post-post-Cold War” period, where old rules are losing influence but a new global consensus has not yet formed.

Humanitarian and financial limits

Humanitarian agencies warn that resources are not infinite: each new war, disaster or refugee surge competes with existing crises for money, staff and political attention.
At the same time, heavily indebted countries face high interest rates, limiting their ability to invest in climate adaptation, healthcare and social protection — and fuelling new cycles of instability.

What to watch next

Analysts say the key questions for 2026 include:

Will any of the major conflicts (Ukraine, Gaza, Sudan) move toward a sustainable peace?

Can governments tackle the cost-of-living crisis without deep cuts to social spending?

Will there be at least minimal cooperation on global issues such as climate and AI, or will states increasingly go it alone?

The answers will determine whether this period of turbulence becomes a passing phase or the start of a longer era of chronic instability.

title: Strategy, Sacrifice and Legacy: A Father’s Journey to Build a Stronger Future
description: A powerful story of resilience, strategy and vision. Balancing fatherhood, pressure and purpose, he turns discipline into strength and obstacles into motivation. Inspired by Abraham Lincoln, his journey proves that greatness is built through persistence and wisdom.
fullText:
Interviewer: Your journey has many layers. Who are you today, and what truly defines you?

Manssuato:
Today, I see myself as a builder not only of projects, but of a future. I am a father of two daughters, a husband, a worker, an entrepreneur and a man who has learned, through pain and discipline, that nothing truly meaningful is ever easy. What defines me is not perfection, but persistence.

The world often sees only the results. Few people see the nights of doubt, the pressure, the responsibility that weighs on your shoulders when you carry other lives in your hands. Being a father changes everything. When you look into your children’s eyes, excuses no longer exist. Only purpose remains.

And it is not easy. None of it is easy.

Interviewer: You often speak about strategy and organisation. Why are these so important to you?

Manssuato:
Without strategy, effort becomes waste. Without organisation, even talent dissolves into chaos. I had to learn that the hard way.

Life forced me to use strategy. Not just in business, but in survival, in planning, in protecting my family and in creating something meaningful from nothing. Every step I take has a reason. I don’t move randomly. I think, analyse, organise and then I act.

I live by a simple rule: “We must be organised, we must be disciplined, and we must be intentional.”

That is how goals are achieved. Not by luck. But by strategy and wisdom.

Interviewer: You mentioned using strong phrases to stay focused. Can you share some of them?

Manssuato:
Yes. I repeat certain phrases in my mind almost like a personal prayer, a mantra. Some of them are:

• “Pressure creates diamonds.”
• “No one will build my future if I don’t.”
• “I don’t need motivation when I have responsibility.”
• “Chaos is the enemy of success.”
• “I was not created to give up.”

And when things get heavy, when doubt tries to break in, I remember a powerful truth inspired by Abraham Lincoln:

“I am a slow walker, but I never walk backwards.”

That sentence is burned into my soul.

Interviewer: How does being a father influence your decisions?

Manssuato:
Being a father changed the way I see time. It made me understand that every minute matters. My daughters are the reason I wake up determined, even when I am tired. They are the reason I must stay strong when I feel weak.

I don’t want them to see a man who gave up. I want them to see discipline, integrity and resilience. I want them to know that their father fought with honour and intelligence.

Nothing I do today is only for me. It is for them. It is legacy.

And legacy is built through choices made under pressure.

Interviewer: Abraham Lincoln is often mentioned as an inspiration to you. Why?

Manssuato:
Because Lincoln represents a man who endured more than most, and yet refused to surrender his vision. He failed in business. He lost elections. He was mocked. But he stood firm in his purpose.

That speaks directly to my own journey. Sometimes I fail. Sometimes I am misunderstood. Sometimes I feel alone. But I continue.

Lincoln once said:

“In the end, it’s not the years in your life that count, it’s the life in your years.”

I live with that in mind. I don’t measure time. I measure impact.

Interviewer: What message would you like people to take from your story?

Manssuato:
That your past does not define your ceiling. Your discipline does.
That you do not need perfect conditions to start. You need courage.
That your struggles are not a curse they are training.

Above all, I want people to understand this:

We must use strategy.
We must use wisdom.
We must stay organised.
And we must never lose focus on our objective.

The world does not give space to the unprepared. But it bows to those who refuse to quit.

Interviewer: Finally, what is your greatest strength today?

Manssuato:
My mind.
My discipline.
My vision.

And my daughters. They are both my weakness and my greatest power.

Because a man with a reason is unstoppable.
And I have two.

title: BTCBRAVE Shows Strong Accumulation Signals as Bearish Pressure Weakens and Momentum Builds for a Breakout
description: BTCBRAVE is showing clear signs of accumulation as selling pressure fades and buyers quietly regain control. The current market structure suggests a potential breakout is forming, with strong upside momentum building.
fullText:
BTCBRAVE Is Holding Its Ground Against Bearish Pressure

In recent trading sessions, BTCBRAVE has demonstrated remarkable resilience, even as broader market sentiment has briefly leaned toward cautious or bearish territory. While some weaker hands have exited their positions, long-term holders and new strategic buyers have taken the opportunity to accumulate at a discount. This behaviour signals confidence rather than fear.

Instead of collapsing under pressure, BTCBRAVE has formed a stable base — a typical sign seen before powerful upward movements.

This phase is not a sign of weakness. On the contrary, it is what experienced traders recognise as “smart accumulation”.

Strong Support Levels Are Forming

One of the most important technical developments is the establishment of a solid support zone. Each time the price dips, it is met with immediate buying interest. This consistent response from the market indicates that investors see strong value in BTCBRAVE at this level.

This type of action is usually seen when a token is preparing to reverse trend direction. Rather than free-falling, the price is carefully being defended, suggesting that larger players may be quietly positioning themselves before a major move.

The market is speaking — and it is saying BTCBRAVE is not finished. It is getting ready.

Momentum Is Building Behind the Scenes

Even during periods of reduced volatility, internal momentum indicators reveal a different story. Volume patterns are starting to show signs of gradual increase, and the absence of panic selling points toward a potential supply squeeze.

When too many sellers disappear, and demand begins to rise, price tends to move aggressively upward. This is basic market physics — and BTCBRAVE appears to be entering that exact stage.

This is the calm before the breakout.

Community Confidence Remains Strong

One of BTCBRAVE’s greatest assets has always been its growing and loyal community. Despite temporary consolidation, interest in the project continues to increase across social channels.

Engagement, wallet growth and brand recognition are slowly rising. That alone suggests something powerful is underway in the background. Most major movements in crypto are preceded by silence — followed by a sudden surge in visibility and volume.

BTCBRAVE is positioning itself for precisely that moment.

title: Russia Rejects U.S. 28‑Point Peace Plan, Demands Ukrainian Surrender
description: Russia has outright rejected the U.S. 28‑point peace plan, demanding Ukraine’s surrender and a demilitarised zone to the Polish border. The West, led by the U.S., remains poised to press Moscow with sanctions and diplomatic pressure while Ukrainian leaders seek a balanced compromise.
fullText:
1. Kremlin’s Firm Stance
Deputy FM Sergei Ryabkov reiterated Moscow’s non‑compromise position at the Alaska summit, insisting that Putin’s demands remain unchanged.
Russia’s “root causes” of the conflict—NATO expansion, the deployment of weapons in Eastern Europe, and alleged discrimination against Russian culture—are still the basis of Moscow’s policy.
2. Russian Officials Keep Pressure on the West
Alexei Zhuravlev criticises the U.S. proposal for endangering Russia’s borders, calling the plan “dangerous.”
Alexei Chepa objects to the transfer of long‑range missiles to Ukraine, saying it contradicts Moscow’s stated goal of demilitarisation.
3. Propaganda and Public Opinion
Vadim Gigin of Belarusian propaganda media warns that the West’s proposals are unacceptable due to mistrust and lack of enforcement mechanisms.
Ultra‑nationalist bloggers continue to reject any peace plan that could limit Russia’s territorial gains, citing a need to continue the war while possible.
4. U.S. 28‑Point Plan Overview
Drafted by Steve Witkoff with Russian consultation, the plan asks Ukraine to:
Surrender parts of unoccupied Donetsk territory.
Reduce its armed forces.
Freeze fronts in Zaporizhzhia and Kherson.
Lift sanctions against Russia.
Provide NATO‑style security guarantees.
Distribute frozen Russian assets and establish a Peace Council.
5. Ukrainian Response
President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was presented the plan on November 20 and warned that Ukraine faces a choice between dignity and partnership.
Zelenskyy remains open to alternatives that keep Ukrainian interests central.
6. U.S. Urgency and Threats
President Trump, citing Reuters, said he wanted the plan in place by Thanksgiving and warned that refusal could suspend intelligence and arms support.
Moscow, however, insists it will not accept any proposal that does not secure full Ukrainian surrender.

title: Progress on Gaza Truce Stalled as Israeli‑Hamas Violence Continues
description: Israeli‑Hamas violence continues to erode a fragile 9‑October truce, with both sides citing breaches and human casualties mounting. A comprehensive resolution hinges on a detailed, mutually accepted security framework and the implementation of the Trump‑backed 20‑point plan.
fullText:
1. Background: The 9‑October Cease‑fire
On 9 October, Hamas and Israel signed an agreement that temporarily halted two years of intense fighting. The deal was hailed worldwide but left several thorny issues unresolved—particularly the administration of Gaza and the exchange of prisoners and remains. Despite the truce, each side has accused the other of violating its terms, undermining confidence in a lasting settlement.

2. Recent Violations and Human Cost
Drone and Artillery Attacks: On 24 November, a drone fired a missile near Khan Younis, killing two Palestinians and wounding a third. A tank shell later struck east of Gaza City, killing one more.
Casualty Totals: Gaza’s Health Ministry reports that at least 342 Palestinians have been killed since the truce began on 10 October. Israel confirms the loss of three of its soldiers in the same period.
3. Hostage and Body Exchange Issues
Body of a Hostage Found: The armed wing of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad announced it had located the body of a hostage in an Israeli‑controlled area of Gaza. The timing of the handover remains unclear.
Remaining Bodies: The original truce called for 28 hostage bodies to be returned in exchange for 360 militant remains. Only three such bodies are still in Gaza.
4. International Negotiations and the Trump Plan
United Nations Endorsement: The UN Security Council formally backed President Donald Trump’s 20‑point plan, which proposes an interim, technocratic Palestinian government in Gaza overseen by an international “peace board” and supported by a multinational security force.
Implementation Challenges: Israel insists that the international force must disarm Hamas, while Hamas demands that Israeli troops stay away from Palestinian civilians. The composition, mandate, and deployment of this force remain undefined.
5. Mediators and Future Phases
Tony Blair’s Involvement: Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair, who helped craft the Trump plan, met with Deputy Leader Hussein al‑Sheikh of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank to discuss self‑determination and the next steps.
Hamas‑Egypt Talks: A Hamas delegation led by Khalil al‑Hayya met Egyptian officials in Cairo to explore the second phase of the truce. Hamas has warned that Israeli violations are obstructing the agreement.
6. Obstacles to a Stable Agreement
Political Stalemate: Israel views a permanent peace only through Hamas’ complete surrender, while Palestinian factions reject any solution that leaves them without a recognized state.
Need for a Coherent Plan: Both sides point to the absence of a detailed, mutually acceptable security arrangement as the main hurdle to establishing a durable cease‑fire and rebuilding Gaza.
7. Looking Ahead
The truce remains fragile, with sporadic violations and unresolved political questions. A lasting resolution will require concrete, enforceable commitments, respect for both sides’ security concerns, and a clearly defined international framework to safeguard civilians and facilitate reconstruction.

title: White House Power Play: Who Will Decide Ukraine’s Destiny?
description: The White House’s internal split—Vance’s pragmatic, “realist” approach versus Rubio’s hard‑line, NATO‑aligned stance—determines whether the U.S. pursues a negotiated settlement that could compromise Ukraine’s security or continues to support Kyiv’s sovereignty and NATO integration. The outcome will shape the future of Western alliances and Ukraine’s fate.
fullText:
1. Two Visions for Kyiv
Inside the Oval Office’s quiet corridors, Vice‑President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio have emerged as the country’s two most powerful advisers on Ukraine. Vance, the pragmatic “realist” of the administration, stresses the need to accept Russia’s battlefield advantage and seeks a negotiated settlement that would let Kyiv cede contested territory. Rubio, a long‑time hawk who famously branded Vladimir Putin a “gangster,” insists that the United States must back a hard‑line stance that keeps Ukraine aligned with NATO’s broader security network.

2. The 28‑Point Proposal – A Russian‑Driven Draft
Last week, Vance took the lead by inviting President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss the 28‑point plan that critics describe as a Russian “wish list.” The draft, prepared by the Trump‑appointed envoy Steve Witkoff and Russia’s top negotiator Kirill Dmitriev, would force Ukraine to abandon fortified positions in Donbas, limit the size of its armed forces, and bar the country from joining NATO. Although the plan was drafted largely behind closed doors, Vance’s endorsement gave it a veneer of White House approval.

3. Rubio’s Counter‑Offensive in Geneva
When President Trump later said the 28‑point plan was not his “final offer,” Rubio stepped into the breach. He spent days negotiating with a Ukrainian delegation in Geneva, pushing back the most contentious demands. By Monday, the original 28 points had been trimmed to a 19‑point document, with the heaviest restrictions removed or postponed. European leaders applauded the softer approach, believing Rubio had become the administration’s primary Ukraine negotiator.

4. A Parallel Peace Track
While Rubio pushed in Geneva, another arm of the White House continued to work on the Witkoff‑driven agenda. The dual processes—Rubio’s public negotiations and Witkoff’s secret meetings with Dmitriev—created confusion among senior advisers. A leaked call revealed Rubio calling the plan a “Russian proposal,” only to later claim it was an American‑crafted compromise that included input from both sides.

5. Internal Turbulence and the Senate’s Role
Sources say the administration’s lack of a unified front has led to chaotic decision‑making. “Different parts of the White House don’t know what’s going on,” an insider told the Washington Post. The final deal will still need Senate approval, especially if it contains security guarantees or treaty‑level commitments. The split between Vance’s accommodationist approach and Rubio’s hard‑line stance has put the President in a dilemma: which vision will ultimately shape U.S. policy toward Ukraine?

6. Looking Ahead – The Stakes for the Western Alliance
Ultimately, the outcome of this internal battle will decide whether the U.S. leans toward a negotiated peace that could weaken Ukraine’s future security or remains steadfast in its support for Kyiv’s sovereignty and alignment with NATO. The next few weeks will reveal whether President Trump can reconcile these competing priorities, or whether a single voice will emerge to dictate the country’s trajectory.
